options.text: A set of instructions that tells the system how to perform a specific task

explanation.summary: A computer program is fundamentally a sequence of instructions written in a programming language that the computer can understand and execute. Think of it like a recipe: just as a recipe provides step-by-step instructions to create a dish, a program provides step-by-step instructions for a computer to perform tasks.
keyPoints: Sequential execution: Instructions are processed in a specific order
Input processing: Programs take data, transform it, and produce output
Machine interaction: Programs communicate directly with hardware components through the operating system
Problem-solving: Each program is designed to solve a particular problem or perform a specific function
examples: A calculator app processes mathematical operations
A web browser retrieves and displays web pages
A video game renders graphics and responds to user input
Microsoft Word processes text and formats documents
explanation.additionalInfo: Without programs (software), computer hardware would be completely useless—like having a car without an engine or fuel. The hardware needs instructions to know what to do with electricity flowing through its circuits.

learnMore.title: GeeksforGeeks - What is a Computer Program?

options.text: A device that is connected to the Internet

explanation.summary: This describes hardware (physical equipment), not software. Examples include routers, smartphones, smart TVs, or IoT devices. While these devices may run programs to connect to the Internet, they are not programs themselves.
explanation.why: The distinction is crucial: hardware is the physical machine, software (programs) is the set of instructions that runs on that machine.

options.text: An interface for interacting with a device such as a laptop or a mobile phone

explanation.summary: This describes a user interface (UI) or graphical user interface (GUI). While a UI is created by a program, it is not the program itself. The UI is just the visual layer that lets humans interact with the underlying program.
explanation.why: For example, the buttons and menus you see in an app are the interface, but the code that makes those buttons work is the actual program.

learnMore.title: Interaction Design Foundation - What is UI Design?
Nielsen Norman Group - UI vs UX

options.text: A document that describes how to build software

explanation.summary: This describes documentation, technical specifications, or software requirements. These are written guides for humans (developers) to understand how to build or use software. Documentation explains about programs but is not executable.
explanation.why: Examples include user manuals, API documentation, or software design documents. You cannot run documentation—it's reference material.

questions.question: What is the role of the motherboard in a computer system?

options.text: It runs a set of instructions

explanation.summary: This is the job of the CPU (Central Processing Unit), also called the processor. The CPU is the 'brain' of the computer that executes program instructions. It performs calculations, makes logical decisions, and coordinates operations.
explanation.why: The motherboard simply provides the socket where the CPU sits and the connections it needs to communicate with other parts. The CPU processes instructions while the motherboard connects the CPU to everything else.

explanation.summary: The motherboard is the main printed circuit board (PCB) in a computer and serves as the central hub that connects all other components together. Think of it as the nervous system of the computer—it doesn't do the thinking (that's the CPU) or remember things (that's RAM), but it provides the pathways for all parts to communicate.
keyPoints: Physical mounting: Provides slots and sockets where components physically attach (CPU socket, RAM slots, PCIe slots)
Electrical connections: Delivers power from the power supply to all components through power connectors and voltage regulators
Data buses: Contains circuits called 'buses' that carry data between components
Chipset coordination: Houses the chipset (controller chips) that manages data flow between the CPU, memory, and peripherals
BIOS/UEFI firmware: Contains basic firmware that initializes hardware during boot before the operating system loads
explanation.analogy: If your computer were a city, the motherboard would be the road system connecting all buildings (components) so they can communicate and share resources.

options.text: It displays information on the screen

explanation.summary: This is handled by the GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) or display adapter, along with the monitor. The GPU processes visual data and renders images, which are then sent to your display.
explanation.why: Some motherboards have integrated graphics built into the CPU/chipset, but the motherboard itself doesn't generate images—it only provides the connection point (HDMI, DisplayPort, or PCIe slot) for display hardware.

explanation.summary: Data storage is handled by storage devices (HDDs, SSDs, NVMe drives) and temporary working memory (RAM). The motherboard provides the SATA ports or M.2 slots where storage devices connect, but it doesn't store data itself.
explanation.why: A small CMOS chip on the motherboard stores BIOS settings, but this is minimal compared to actual data storage.

questions.question: Which components are a physical part of a computer system? (Select TWO.)

explanation.summary: This is software—a program that runs on hardware. A web application server (like Apache, Nginx, or IIS) is software that listens for incoming web requests, processes them, and sends back responses.
explanation.why: While it may run on a physical server machine, the 'web application server' itself refers to the software component, not the hardware. The physical server is the actual machine (hardware), while the web server software is the program running on that machine (software).

learnMore.title: NGINX - What is a Web Server?
GeeksforGeeks - Web Server and Application Server

explanation.summary: A network card is a physical circuit board or chip that enables a computer to connect to a network. It can be a discrete card (a separate expansion card inserted into a PCIe slot), integrated (built into the motherboard chipset), or come in various form factors like Ethernet cards, Wi-Fi adapters, or Bluetooth modules.
keyPoints: Converts digital data into electrical signals or radio waves
Provides a MAC address (unique hardware identifier)
Handles data packet transmission and reception
Manages network protocols at the hardware level
explanation.identification: If you can plug an Ethernet cable into it or see a Wi-Fi antenna attached to it, it's physical hardware.

learnMore.title: CompTIA - What is a Network Interface Card?

explanation.summary: The motherboard is the main circuit board with visible slots, chips, capacitors, and connectors. You can physically install it in a computer case, attach cables to it, and mount components on it.
explanation.identification: It's a tangible, physical component you can touch and hold.

explanation.summary: An operating system (Windows, macOS, Linux) is system software—not hardware. The OS is a complex program that manages hardware resources, runs applications, and provides a user interface. You cannot touch an operating system; you can only see its interface and effects.
explanation.why: The OS exists as files stored on a hard drive and loaded into RAM when the computer boots.

explanation.summary: Like 'web application server,' this typically refers to database software (MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB, Oracle Database) that manages data storage and retrieval. While it runs on physical server hardware, the term 'database server' describes the software role, not a physical component.
explanation.why: You can have database server software running on any computer. The physical machine hosting it would be called a 'server' (hardware), but 'database server' as a term primarily means the software application.

questions.question: Which statements describe random access memory (RAM)? (Select TWO.)

options.text: It can be a hard disk drive (HDD) or a solid state drive (SSD)

explanation.summary: HDDs and SSDs are storage devices, not RAM. They serve completely different purposes despite both holding data.
explanation.comparison: RAM: Active working memory, extremely fast (nanoseconds), volatile (erases when powered off), 8-64 GB typical, expensive per GB. Storage (HDD/SSD): Long-term storage, much slower (microseconds to milliseconds), non-volatile (keeps data when powered off), 256 GB to 4 TB typical, cheaper per GB.
explanation.why: The confusion exists because both store data, but they operate in completely different speed tiers of the memory hierarchy. Your operating system uses both together: storage holds your files permanently, RAM holds active work temporarily for fast access.

explanation.summary: RAM is volatile memory, meaning it only retains data while the computer is powered on. The moment you shut down or restart your computer, everything in RAM is erased. This temporary nature is by design and serves several purposes.
keyPoints: RAM uses transistor-based circuits that are extremely fast but require constant power
Each boot starts with a clean slate, preventing corrupted data from persisting
Sensitive data (passwords, encryption keys) doesn't remain after shutdown, which provides security benefits
whatRAMStores: Currently running programs and their active data
Open documents you're working on (before saving)
Operating system components actively in use
Recently accessed files for quick retrieval
explanation.analogy: RAM is like your desk workspace—you keep papers and tools there while working, but at the end of the day, you file everything away (save to storage) and clear your desk.

learnMore.title: Crucial - What Does Computer Memory (RAM) Do?

explanation.summary: This is the opposite of how RAM works. Persistent storage means data remains even when power is removed—that's what storage devices (HDD, SSD, USB drives) do. RAM loses all contents immediately when power is cut.
implications: You should save your work often because your work in RAM can be lost in a power outage
Sleep mode keeps RAM powered (fast resume but uses battery)
Hibernate saves RAM contents to disk then powers off (slower but saves battery)
Files in RAM cannot be recovered after unexpected shutdown unless they were saved to storage

options.text: It is made to store applications, documents, and programs

explanation.summary: This describes long-term storage (HDD/SSD), not RAM. The confusion arises because RAM temporarily holds copies of programs and documents while you're using them, but it's not designed for storage.
howItWorks: Storage permanently holds your installed programs and saved files
When you open a program, it's copied from storage into RAM
The program runs in RAM where it can be accessed quickly
When you close the program, it's removed from RAM
The original program remains safely on storage
explanation.analogy: Storage is like a filing cabinet (permanent), RAM is like your desk (temporary workspace). You take files from the cabinet to your desk to work on them, then put them back.

explanation.summary: RAM is one of the fastest types of memory in a computer, with access times measured in nanoseconds (billionths of a second). This speed is crucial for system performance.
speedComparison: SSDs: 50-150 microseconds (1,000 times slower than RAM)
HDDs: 5-10 milliseconds (100,000 times slower than RAM)
whyFast: Direct electrical connection to the CPU via the memory bus
No moving parts (unlike HDDs where mechanical components slow down access)
Random access (any memory location can be accessed instantly without reading through other data)
Parallel processing (modern RAM can access multiple memory locations simultaneously)
explanation.performanceImpact: When RAM is insufficient, the computer uses 'virtual memory' (swapping to the hard drive), which causes dramatic slowdowns because storage is thousands of times slower than RAM.

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of operating systems? (Select TWO.)

explanation.summary: iOS is Apple's mobile operating system that powers iPhones, iPads, and iPod Touch devices. It's built on a Unix-like foundation and provides complete operating system functionality.
keyFunctions: Process management (runs and switches between apps)
File system operations (organizes and protects files using APFS)
User interface (provides the touchscreen interface called SpringBoard)
Security (app sandboxing, encryption, Face ID/Touch ID)
Hardware drivers (manages camera, GPS, cellular radio, sensors)

explanation.summary: 'Oracle' most commonly refers to Oracle Database, which is database management software, not an operating system. Oracle Corporation makes many products, but when people say 'Oracle' without context, they usually mean the database.
explanation.why: Oracle Database is a software application that runs on top of an operating system. Its purpose is to manage storage, retrieval, and manipulation of structured data. It requires an OS and must be installed on Windows, Linux, or Unix. It's not standalone and cannot boot a computer or manage hardware directly.
explanation.confusion: The confusion arises because Oracle Corporation also makes other products including Oracle Solaris (which is an operating system), but 'Oracle' alone refers to their flagship database product. The key distinction is that an operating system is the foundation that manages hardware, while a database is an application that runs on an operating system.

explanation.summary: Amazon Linux 2 is a Linux distribution provided by Amazon Web Services (AWS), designed for running applications in cloud environments. It's based on Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) and CentOS.
keyFeatures: Multi-user support (multiple users can work simultaneously)
Package management (uses yum/RPM for software installation)
File system support (typically uses ext4 or xfs)
Process scheduling (manages CPU allocation for processes)

explanation.summary: MySQL Server is database server software, similar to Oracle Database but open-source. It's an application that must run on an operating system.
whatItDoesNot: Handle user login at the system level
explanation.architecture: Applications → MySQL Server (Database Application) → Operating System (Linux, Windows, etc.) → Hardware

explanation.summary: Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) is a cloud computing service, not an operating system. It's infrastructure that lets you run operating systems, but it's not an OS itself.
whatIsEC2: A cloud service that provides virtual servers in AWS data centers
Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) where you rent computing resources
A platform on which you install operating systems
Accessed through AWS console, API, or CLI
howItRelates: You create an EC2 instance (virtual machine)
You then choose an operating system to install (Amazon Linux 2, Windows Server, Ubuntu, etc.)
That OS runs on the virtual hardware provided by EC2
You then install your applications on that OS
explanation.analogy: EC2 is like a hosting company that provides the computer (virtual hardware). You still need to install an operating system on that computer, just like buying a blank PC and installing Windows or Linux on it.
explanation.keyDistinction: EC2 is the service that provides virtual computers, while the operating system is the software you install on those virtual computers.
